# UD Abkhaz AbNC

Language: [Abkhaz](/ab/index.html) (code: `ab`)<br/>
Family: Northwest Caucasian

This treebank has been part of Universal Dependencies since the UD v2.14 release.

The following people have contributed to making this treebank part of UD: Paul Meurer.

Repository: [UD_Abkhaz-AbNC](https://github.com/UniversalDependencies/UD_Abkhaz-AbNC)<br />
Search this treebank on-line: [PML-TQ](https://lindat.mff.cuni.cz/services/pmltq/#!/treebank/udab_abnc214)<br />
Download all treebanks: [UD 2.14](/#download)

Genre: fiction

You can report bugs in this treebank in the [treebank-specific issue tracker on Github](https://github.com/UniversalDependencies/UD_Abkhaz-AbNC/issues).

Development of the treebank happens directly in the UD repository, so you may submit bug fixes as pull requests against the dev branch.

## Description

UD_Abkhaz-AbNC is a treebank based on texts from the Abkhaz National Corpus, [AbNC](https://clarino.uib.no/abnc).



UD_Abkhaz-AbNC is a treebank based on texts from the Abkhaz National Corpus, [AbNC](https://clarino.uib.no/abnc), which is a corpus of written texts from a variety of genres. The sentences for the initial release of the treebank are taken from a collection of fairy tales for children (Аҧсуа лакәқәа – Ахәыҷқәа рзы, editor: Мықәба, А.).

The sentences are analysed using a finite state morphological analyser, and Constraint Grammar rules for disambiguation and dependency parsing. Both disambiguation and dependency analyses are corrected manually in a tool specifically developed for that purpose.

## Acknowledgments

The Abkhaz treebank and the tools used to create it have been developed by Paul Meurer.

I am grateful to Saida Adzhindzhal (Suchum) for helping me understanding some of the constructions in the texts.

## References

* Paul Meurer. A finite state approach to Abkhaz morphology and stress. Lecture Notes in Computer Science 2011, Volume 6618. pp. 271-282.
* Paul Meurer. The Abkhaz National Corpus. Proceedings of the Eleventh International Conference on Language Resources and Evaluation (LREC 2018), Miyazaki, Japan 2018. pp. 2456–2460.
* Paul Meurer. [Towards a Treebank of Abkhaz. The AbNC, Analysing Abkhaz, and the Importance of Good Tools](https://doi.org/10.62235/dk.2.2023.7477). Digital Kartvelology, Volume II (2023).

          <li>VERB-Fin: рыцәцеит, рыцәҩашьеит, ҳрыцәшәоит</li>
          <li>VERB-NonFin: Изуцәызӡарызеи, исцәызгозеи, ишзацәымцоз, иҳацәшәо, ҳашрыцәшәоз</li>
        </ul>
      </li>
      <li>Pot
        <ul>
          <li>VERB-Fin: азхамҵеит, азыгәаҕьуамызт, изымцеит, исызуҭаӡом, рзымуит, шәзеилымкаацт</li>
          <li>VERB-NonFin: Исзымдыруа, Иузымдыруа, сзымдыруа, узымдырӡои, шҧашәзеилымкаац</li>
        </ul>
      </li>
    </ul>
  </li>
</ul>

<ul>
  <li><a>Trans</a>
    <ul>
      <li>No
        <ul>
          <li>VERB-Fin: иалагеит, иаацәажәеит, сықәыртәа, акәхеит, иаагылеит, иаахәыцит, иааҵашәеит, иналагеит, инеиуан, ицеит</li>
          <li>VERB-NonFin: иаҳаз, Ишәыхьзеи, Иҟалаз, иааҭгыланы, ианынаскьа, инамҵасны, инеины, ишнеиуаз, Дышнеиуаз, Иаауаз</li>
          <li>VERB-Vnoun: ашәаҳәара, ныҟәара, Ақәҧара, абыбра, агылараҵәҟьа, агәаара, ажаҳәара, аисра, аиқәҧара, арыцқьара</li>
        </ul>
      </li>
      <li>Yes
        <ul>
          <li>VERB-Fin: аҳәеит, аҳәан, аҿынанахеит, иҳәеит, рҳәеит, сибоит, ҿааиҭит, ҿаанаҭит, еилыскааит, еимаркит</li>
          <li>VERB-NonFin: умбои, иаҳәаз, Иазууазеи, изуҭахузеи, иҟауҵо, уҭахымзар, ӡаны, Амшәгьы, Еилукаазар, Иазызуазеи</li>
          <li>VERB-Vnoun: аҳәара, аизгара, Афароуп, ааҧхьара, анагӡара, аҧшаара, аҳара, рыфара</li>
        </ul>
      </li>
    </ul>
  </li>
</ul>

<h2>Syntax</h2>

<h3>Auxiliary Verbs and Copula</h3>

<ul>
<li>This corpus uses 1 lemmas as copulas (<a>cop</a>). Examples: а́кәзаара.</li>
</ul>

<ul>
<li>This corpus does not contain auxiliaries.</li>
</ul>

<h3>Core Arguments, Oblique Arguments and Adjuncts</h3>

Here we consider only relations between verbs (parent) and nouns or pronouns (child).
<ul>
  <li><a>nsubj</a>
    <ul>
      <li>VERB-Fin--NOUN (138)</li>
      <li>VERB-Fin--PRON (41)</li>
      <li>VERB-NonFin--NOUN (40)</li>
      <li>VERB-NonFin--PRON (20)</li>
    </ul>
  </li>
</ul>

<ul>
  <li><a>obj</a>
    <ul>
      <li>VERB-Fin--NOUN (49)</li>
      <li>VERB-Fin--PRON (9)</li>
      <li>VERB-NonFin--NOUN (33)</li>
      <li>VERB-NonFin--PRON (8)</li>
      <li>VERB-Vnoun--NOUN (6)</li>
    </ul>
  </li>
</ul>

<ul>
  <li><a>iobj</a>
    <ul>
      <li>VERB-Fin--NOUN (5)</li>
      <li>VERB-Fin--PRON (3)</li>
      <li>VERB-NonFin--NOUN (9)</li>
      <li>VERB-NonFin--PRON (6)</li>
    </ul>
  </li>
</ul>




<h3>Relations Overview</h3>

<ul>
<li>This corpus uses 20 relation subtypes: <a>acl:relcl</a>, <a>advcl:cond</a>, <a>advcl:conv</a>, <a>advcl:purp</a>, <a>advcl:quote</a>, <a>advcl:seq</a>, <a>advmod:q</a>, <a>ccomp:iobj</a>, <a>ccomp:obj</a>, <a>ccomp:purp</a>, <a>ccomp:quote</a>, <a>compound:prt</a>, <a>nmod:poss</a>, <a>nmod:quote</a>, <a>obj:lo</a>, <a>obj:po</a>, <a>obj:poss</a>, <a>obj:ro</a>, <a>xcomp:lo</a>, <a>xcomp:obj</a></li>
<li>The following 1 main types are not used alone, they are always subtyped: <a>acl</a></li>
<li>The following 9 relation types are not used in this corpus at all: <a>expl</a>, <a>dislocated</a>, <a>aux</a>, <a>clf</a>, <a>fixed</a>, <a>list</a>, <a>goeswith</a>, <a>reparandum</a>, <a>dep</a></li>
</ul>
